The general trend is that everyone is struggling with mobile adoption growth.  Mobile is happening – and it’s happening fast – but, it’s still around 2-4% of online.  Everyone wants mobile to grow more quickly, and while struggling to support what they have, many companies simply turn mobile on and, wait for customers to show up with little or no promotion. Similarly, in both geographies, travel and financial services lead the way.  These verticals have higher adoption rates and the most mature solutions in each region around the world.  Many of these companies are on their second or third major version of their mobile offering. The retail vertical is poised for explosive growth in mobile commerce, and is waiting for retailers to fully commit to the mobile channel. Research has shown that when you add mobile channels online visits permanently increase, with an even split between mobile web and native applications.  This means that those US and European companies that are still wrestling with whether to support transactions on mobile web or native applications – urgently need to step up and deliver on both.  All channels are not equal, however.  The Asian execs see similar transaction conversion rate differences to what we see in North America.  In particular, we see iPhone native applications having 30 percent higher conversion rates than other channels (including Android native apps and mobile web).  We expect this behavior to change over time as devices change, and users and companies, are more experienced with mobile. It’s clearer than ever to me that mobile is driving innovation through all its incarnations and across every channel of the business from bricks-and-mortar, to online and beyond. und.safe_value: As tech gurus around the world pay their respects to Steve Jobs following his unfortunate death last week, the mobile industry is left wondering about the future.  Without a doubt, as one of the world’s most amazing innovators, there are not only questions about what route Apple will take next, but also what steps will follow in the mobile industry. Having revolutionized the smartphone market with the iPhone, Apple set the pace, and other mobile providers were left catching up.  Since then, the market has changed quite considerably, and with Android gaining an impressive lead in the mobile space, the top spot for mobile hasn’t been a sure thing for a while.  That being said, everyone will always remember the first. Led by Jobs, Apple continued to keep the industry guessing with its introduction of the iPhone 4, and this week the iPhone 5 was widely anticipated – until it didn’t arrive.  Yet again, Apple has shown that the hype around its products can influence the market.  There have been many comments of disappointment following the absent iPhone 5 announcement, but this only serves to fuel even more rumors of the follow up to the iPhone 4S. The question is – who will be the next visionary, what will be the next innovation to transform the mobile world?  Will it be a new device, a charismatic figure, perhaps a completely new mobile technology – or even an innovative new mobile app platform? Crucially, no-one can predict the future, and nothing stays new forever, particularly when it comes to mobile.  This presents a massive issue for businesses and their marketing teams.  For consumers, having a shiny new phone is exciting, but for enterprises, a new device entering the market can often mean chaos.  As organizations rush to support the new device, many forget that consumers want to take advantage of the unique features of the handset – because of this, businesses need to ensure they are providing a feature-rich experience for users, and they need to do it quickly.  The best option for businesses is to quit the guessing game and implement technology that works from a unique single code based platform, on which quality apps can be built to meet the demands of all devices, and all consumers, as new devices are brought on to the market.  Essentially, businesses need to future-proof. The iPhone 4S and Jobs’ untimely death, have shocked the mobile world – sparking personal tributes and uncertain share prices.  Above all, both have shown that the legacy of innovation always stands strong.

und.safe_value: In my last post, Can Mobile Help Healthcare? I discussed how important expectations, experience, and efficiency are to U.S. consumers.  In this post, we’ll look into how mobile can help you set reasonable expectations for your customers. Should They? I had breakfast with a friend at the nearby Metro Diner (try the crabcakes benedict!) and while we were waiting for our food, I did some admittedly unscientific primary market research with him.  I told him I had just bought a new LCD TV at what I thought was a fair price, and asked him how much he thought I paid.  He asked three questions:  How big? (Ans: 46”)  What brand? (Ans: Sony) and Just the TV? or TV, installation, mounting, extended warranty, etc? (Ans: Just the TV).  Without hesitation he said, “Between $750 and $1,000.” Since he answered so quickly, I asked how he’d have answered if he didn’t know off-hand, or how he’d determine what his alternatives were (different brand, plasma instead of LCD, etc.).  He said he’d go to Google Shopping, or if in the store, use a barcode-scanning app like RedLaser.  Interesting – he already had some expectations based on product details, quality/brand, and his experience, but he also knew how to find the info if he didn’t know immediately. Then I asked him how much an MRI costs.  Blank stare.  I said, “What if I told you it was $300…or $1000, or $3000?” He said, “I don’t  know. “ I asked, “What alternatives are there?  Is an X-Ray just as good?” “I don’t know.” Is it Possible for Healthcare? A few sources for healthcare prices are already available.  For example, Medicare prices provide a good baseline, as does Healthcare Blue Book, which also offers information to help identify treatment options and alternatives.  Having access to this info is good – but if a patient has to use a desktop/laptop to do research, it causes unnecessary delays to gather information to make an informed decision.  Fortunately, last month Healthcare Blue Book announced their mobile app, which empowers the consumer to have that info on hand, during the conversation with their clinician. Current Challenges and The Future One of the biggest challenges of giving health consumers more accurate expectations is that consumers may not know what is wrong with them and what they need as a result.  This makes “shopping” difficult.  Additionally, the available health quality resources typically focus on clinical quality measures/outcomes, which are only one facet of quality. In the future, as clinicians become more retail-oriented, patients become more savvy, and information resources become more integrated, solutions will emerge that let patients filter by their own price and quality attributes.  For example: Some patients may seek the lowest price – probably for the most routine items like vaccinations and checkups.  Others may want best quality, regardless of price – probably for life-saving treatments like cancer, transplants, and cardiac care.  Some may search based on convenience, or other aspects like a nice waiting room, pleasant staff, or other amenities (free coffee or internet access while you wait, for example). The conclusion is that consumers are using mobile technology to inform their purchase decisions today, and increasingly will be doing so for their health decisions in the future.  The only question you have to answer is, “When they do, do you want your offering to show up in their search results?” Please leave a comment with your thoughts on how mobile’s potential to inform consumer expectations in healthcare.

From a business strategy standpoint, organizations must therefore ensure that their investment in mobile caters to any development across the market, whether it be in new technologies, such as NFC and HTML5, or significant changes to operating systems, such as the current iOS5 headache. Those companies that have applied a future-looking, comprehensive mobile strategy that protects them against future disruption will certainly be forerunners in securing the significant revenue opportunities currently at stake in mobile. und.safe_value: Late last week, various figures on consumer mobile device adoption were released, all clearly showing that the once-dominant Apple platform has lost its seemingly unbreakable hold on the mobile market in the third quarter of 2011. Samsung overtook Apple’s device sales with a 44 percent jump, and Android surged past Apple’s iOS platform claiming 50% of the UK’s whole smartphone market. This comes as a worry for the many businesses and organizations that have chosen to focus their resources on just the Apple platform and devices when developing mobile apps. Indeed, it has been a common trend for organizations to short-sightedly roll out just Apple iOS apps due to the platform’s immense popularity, mistaking this for an entire mobile strategy. Unfortunately for those businesses, the rate at which new devices and platforms are constantly hitting the market means the mobile world is progressively becoming more fragmented, making the industry’s future increasingly difficult to predict. Investing in the ‘platform of the moment’ may seem like a good way to get a foot on the mobile ladder – but ultimately, this short-term strategy will just end up being a wasteful endeavor as the war of the mobile platforms intensifies. As clearly demonstrated by the latest figures showing Apple’s apparent decline, a guessing game of what will remain popular is a dangerous one. However, organizations aren’t required to gamble by choosing just one platform when it comes to mobile app development. With the right technology, a complete mobile offering can rely on a single code base that is adaptable and designed to continually optimize each and every new platform or device that comes on the market. By future-proofing their mobile strategy in this way, businesses are guaranteeing their return on investment – they can create feature-rich customer experiences on every platform without getting bogged down in the technicalities of mobile development, and without worrying about whether the platform they’ve chosen will stay in vogue. No matter how brilliant an app is, if it is only accessible on one platform, it will not reap the monetary rewards that mobile apps have the potential to bring in. Businesses who aren’t taking their mobile strategies by the horns with future-proofed, comprehensive mobile apps across all platforms will soon get left behind.

und.safe_value: Back in September, we blogged about the breakneck speed of mobile growth across the globe and how, from ownership figures to usage amounts to the value of the market itself, the mobile market was booming faster than ever. A few key pieces of research released recently have clearly revealed that the mobile industry is showing no signs of slowing down. Firstly, it’s been reported that smartphone apps are set to pass the one million mark within the coming days. With the extent at which the popularity of apps have boomed, it’s hard to believe that the mobile app market is just three and a half years old – we’re currently seeing a whopping average of 2,000 applications enter the mobile marketplace each day. This figure will no doubt only continue to increase, and organizations that don’t have mobile apps as part of their business strategies are missing out on huge revenue opportunities. Gartner has also recently released its “Gartner Predicts 2012” report, which provides a variety of insightful outlooks for the year to come in the portable devices market.  The report states that “the pace of change [in the mobile and tablet space] over the next four years will be breathtaking”, and Gartner believes that smartphones and tablets will represent more than 90% of new net growth in device adoption in the coming four years, and this will then result in most client-side applications being made mobile only or mobile first. Furthermore, according to Gartner, the number of mobile and tablet app development projects will outnumber the number of native PC projects by 4:1 in 2015. The report also states that at least 50% of enterprise email users will rely on a browser, tablet or mobile client, instead of a desktop, by 2016. To me, these statistics don’t just represent a huge growth in volume of the mobile market. Much more important than the large figures is that these developments as a whole signify a huge change in the world’s perception of mobile. These reports have shown that no longer are mobiles and tablets considered luxury products, and no longer are mobile services viewed as add-ons to the consumer or enterprise experience. While consumer mobile apps are already considered a staple part of business to consumer relationships, Gartner’s report shows that businesses are also increasingly comfortable with incorporating portable devices such as smartphones and tablets for enterprise operations. Clearly, mobile apps will only continue to infiltrate every part of our lives, and all organizations need to ensure that mobile strategies are incorporated into their business plans as a whole – otherwise, they will quickly fall behind the competition.

und.safe_value: I recently hosted a joint webinar with Michael J King, Research Director at Gartner on the very-hot topic of HTML5 vs. Native Mobile Apps, during which we discussed the advantages of utilizing HTML5 in the development of mobile apps, the challenges it may pose, and how organizations can ultimately maximize the opportunities that HTML5 presents.  While I won’t delve into those details in this blog post (do check out the webinar if you’re interested!), I will explore how we think HTML5 will impact the mobile landscape in the near future. To briefly summarize Kony’s point of view on the subject, we certainly believe that HTML5 will continue to be a significant factor the mobile space – so much so that our recently launched KonyOne 4.0 platform offers the most complete HTML5 support available on the market. HTML5 will be a key force behind powering single page apps and offering a snappier mobile web experience, which will help fuel an explosive growth of web apps that ultimately deliver an overall better user experience. However, we expect an even bigger interest in hybrid apps - native apps that include HTML5 alongside native elements – as there are certainly benefits to both. According to Michael, “it’s important for companies not to think of HTML5 as an ‘either/or’, as it will be important to support both native and web-based deployment models”. We were also very interested in hearing what you all have to say about the topic, so we conducted a survey of the webinar attendees, which consisted of more than 130 technology executives and mobile developers from global businesses. The responses were telling – when asked whether they are considering launching an HTML5 site for their company, a whopping 74 percent of respondents said yes. Clearly, HTML5 is already on the business agenda for the majority of organizations. Notably, when asked what the most attractive quality of HTML5 is, 82 percent of respondents stated that it was the ability to deploy on all kinds of phones and devices. While better quality apps are undoubtedly a benefit of HTML5, only 13 percent thought an improved design, animation and transition ability was the most attractive quality. Finally, just 5 percent expressed a preference for native applications. These figures clearly show that the main concern currently gripping the market is not so much the quality of the apps themselves (although this is no doubt integral to a successful mobile strategy), but how apps can be deployed across the fragmented realm of numerous different devices and operating systems. The final consideration for businesses is whether to invest in the development of HTML5 websites, native or mixed mode applications.  However, flexibility and agility are essential attributes for any organization wishing to survive in today’s volatile market – and there is no need to take potentially costly gambles on any single technology. In short, when it comes to gaining a competitive edge with a superior mobile offering, KonyOne 4.0 will always be the safest bet.

und.safe_value: With the mobile market more important than ever, Yahoo’s recent statement about adopting a “mobile first” approach  is a strategic and potentially lucrative move.  At the same time however, the company discontinued ten of its mobile apps that had failed to attract large audiences, underscoring how critical it is for companies to think long-term about their mobile strategy, and build apps that truly engage customers. Companies are shifting their thinking, recognizing that customer engagement doesn’t begin with a website, and can’t rely on mass market “push” campaigns.  Instead, it must start with offering customers valuable, personalized content exactly where & when they want it. If you need proof that mobile is driving strategy more than ever before, consider Gartner’s prediction that by the end of 2014, more than 185 billion applications will have been downloaded from mobile app stores. Today’s organizations are starting to realise that mobile cannot be an afterthought.  Instead, mobile should drive development and communications.  Any business that thinks short-term risks losing its investment in mobile application development, as apps that are poor quality or fail to engage customers will be unsuccessful or simply redundant when new technologies storm the market place. The key to longevity in a mobile strategy is to work with a platform provider that incorporates the latest technology – for example, HTML5.  This is the only way for companies to maximize their investments and truly achieve sustainability in a mobile offering. Mobile strategies don’t necessarily get easier for bigger companies either.  A major consumer brand such as Yahoo must simultaneously reach millions of consumers across many mobile devices and its strategy needs to be executed on multiple channels.   In my experience at Kony, most of our customers – which include some of the world’s largest users of mobile – swear by a “mixed mode” approach which takes the best of both worlds from both native applications and HTML5. Our future-proofed technology encompasses all forms of mobile within a single code base.  For Kony customers, there is no need to choose, and new elements to a mobile strategy can be tailored, added and deployed with a simple press of a button. With mobile now fully integrated in our day-to-day lives, it’s clear that getting your mobile strategy right is more important than ever.  The wrong mobile solution could cost a company in reputation, wasted cycles and sales leads, while getting it right will pay off tenfold. What do you think of Yahoo’s new approach?

Consumer demand for smartphones and tablets has exploded in recent years. Nearly everyone today has a mobile device that lets users check email, surf the web, and upload pictures and videos to the Internet. This phenomenon has left many organizations grappling with an important question: How can companies use these consumer-oriented devices in a business context, while at the same time mitigating the information security risks, development costs, and management complexities that can result from their use? The answer to this question lies in the “bring your own device” model. Accelerate Your BYOD StrategyIn the BYOD model, employees use their personal mobile devices to access company applications and information. But before your business embarks on a BYOD model, here are some key tips to remember. Your BYOD strategy should include a flexible mobile enterprise application platform (MEAP) that allows you to focus on three important components: develop, deploy, and manage:

  • Develop. Your company’s MEAP should allow developers to write code once and deploy it to multiple devices from manufacturers like Apple, Windows, Android, BlackBerry, and more, supporting multiple channels including Native, HTML5, Hybrid, Mobile Web, Windows Desktop, and Desktop Web. It should also enable developers to connect and synchronize to various enterprise information systems such as SAP ERP applications, databases, and web services. In addition, the company’s MEAP should be able to include applications that are available for online or offline use with a complete sync framework.
  • Deploy. To deploy applications written by developers, businesses must have access to an enterprise app store that allows for the provisioningof applications across all mobile platforms based on roles, security, and licensing terms. These apps should then be deployed based on certain policies and roles in a secure mobile application container.
  • Manage. To manage application distribution and management before and after deployment, administrators should have access to a web portal that allows them to assign policies to the developed applications, assign applications to users/groups/roles, and promote the applications in the enterprise app store. The administrative portal should provide tools to manage application policies, device policies, user registration, device registry, synchronization, security, logging, and configuration, to name a few.

Also, your company’s BYOD strategy must allow for the quick creation of employee consumable applications. Consider teaming up with a partner who can provide pre-built configurable applications that are completely customizable and extensible so you can ensure you have mobile apps that fit your unique environment. Preferably, these applications will be built from a service-based model, meaning they can be connected to multiple back ends from SAP or non-SAP software, and will be available in a connected and a disconnected mode that is run securely in your partner’s container. We all have our own preferences; it’s the truth. So why not build your company’s mobile strategy with the technologies that you prefer? While closed platforms, development languages and device form factors can sometimes feel like the only way, an open approach enables you to lean on your preferences, invest in non-proprietary technology and lower or even eliminate the risk of vendor lock-in. Not convinced that open is the feasible for your organization? Here are 3 more reasons why you can – and should -- take this high road approach.  1. Unique user experience. A major factor in mobile application adoption is user experience by application design. Organizations looking to develop mobile applications to improve their brand loyalty, customer service, or even employee productivity should use open approaches that give them the flexibility to make design decisions rather than be limited by specific mobile OS or other technology options. With an open approach you can add cool widgets easily to your mobile apps. This is a great advantage over closed approaches because you can pick from open third-party libraries  offered by the industries’ finest including Sencha, jQuery, Node.js, Dojo and more. The more compelling your consumer application is the better your chance of improving brand loyalty and even beating out the competition. Meanwhile, employees can benefit from simple widgets in their apps, which results in higher productivity and work place satisfaction. 2. Versatile support and integration. Mobile applications penetrated the market when affordable consumer smartphones were released. These devices are the entry point for mobile apps today by both consumers and employees. Companies that use an open approach are able to build and deploy their apps to any channel including:

  • Smartphones
  • Tablets
  • Kiosks
  • Desktops
  • Feature Phones

A closed approach would only allow you to build and deploy to a few of these device types. An open approach supports you to offer your apps on any device without compromise. It is important to note that technologies like HTML5 are also considered to be a channel and could, in the future, define the next level of mobile web. Ensuring that HTML5 is part of your open mobility strategy will future-proof your plans and investments. Devices have all sorts of accessories that users expect to be part of the mobile app experience. Open standards allow you to extend mobile apps using foreign function interface (FFI). This approach allows you include third-party workflows like barcode scanners, augmented reality, and diagnostic sensors in our mobile app experience. 3. Organizational agility and innovation. According to the Enterprise Mobility Forum, “BYOD is currently one of the most frequently discussed issues in enterprise mobility”.  Enterprise organizations that take an open approach to their mobility strategy are better equipped to implement a Bring-Your-Own-Device (BYOD) program. An BYOD IT Guide notes that “most recently, IT managers have begun viewing BYOD as an opportunity for driving organizational effectiveness, rather than just a syndrome to fight or avoid. Although a handful organizations have embarked on BYOD merely to save on capital equipment costs and improve their bottom line in the short term, many IT organizations have viewed the potential for lost or stolen data from the use of personal devices as not worth these savings. But recently, businesses have realized that there is more to this trend than just the tangible short-term gain. The cost saving momentum of BYOD has now been superseded by more strategic, long-term benefits of employee engagement, increased productivity, organizational agility and innovation.” With these reasons, you should now at least consider an open approach to your mobile strategy. If you’re already convinced, now is the time to explore your options and find the industry’s most open standard based technology, and yes, we will help you find it!

As the US automotive industry finds itself back on its feet and sales back on the upswing, employees in automakers’ R&D and forward-looking business areas are once more spending time on advanced user-experience (UX) road-mapping (pardon the pun), and delivering to the owner - or his employer - a 360 degree experience of the vehicle. From product research to purchasing and maintenance, from in-car entertainment and communications, to trade-in and re-engagement with the dealership ; customers can expect to have a soup-to-nuts one-to-one relationship with their vehicles with daily interactions and updates to keep the relationship fresh and engaging. Mobility, of course, is a key delivery channel for this relationship. Few cars would continue to communicate reliably with an Ethernet cable trailing from their HMI (human-machine interface, or ‘head’ unit). To achieve this tighter relationship between driver and vehicle, each of the actors in the industry must play far more closely with each other as they have done so far :

  1. OEMs. The vehicle manufacturers themselves can no longer go-it-alone in a connected world. Their head units, for example, can today communicate with each component of the vehicle and deliver a heads-up report of wear-and-tear, status, levels, when-to-service etc. – along with staples such as GPS-fed location and FM/HD radio-fed traffic data. But what about the driver who wants to see all of this on his smartphone or tablet, from anywhere ? What if you’ve locked yourself out of your car simply prefer to click a couple of buttons on your vehicle’s iPhone App over speaking with someone?  All of this (and much, much more) requires OEMs to embrace mobility providers. Indeed the HMI itself needs to provide in-car users with Facebook, web radio, and other road trip essentials. Will using a proprietary operating system really attract developers or would using an Android or other widely-supported platform be a better bet ?
  2. Dealerships. OEMs and dealerships have always had somewhat of a disjointed relationship. When a car is bought from a dealership – often with on-site provided financing – the customer relationship for the warranty period at least is with the dealership, with the financial relationship lying with a 3rd party.  Dealerships and OEMs working together, for example, on the ‘Brand X SUV’ iPhone App, can ensure a lifetime relationship between owner and car. Alerts (both push and pull) for all manner of on-vehicle data can be enabled for the driver to choose from. Want to find out where little Johnny is while you’re on vacation ?  What about his braking patterns and how much his friends use Facebook on those trips ?  Imagination is literally the only barrier to such use cases.  The relationship between OEMs and dealerships can also benefit from mobility, including in areas such as education, sales training, special offers, retail pass-throughs and more.
  3. Suppliers. There are many tiers of suppliers in automotive, serving mainly B2B (business to business) and B2E (business to employee) segments. Dealer management systems,  services management and other after-market areas are ripe for innovation with a mobility strategy, with sales reps for example being empowered with all the information and execution tools they need while on the lot - down to remote keyless unlock of a vehicle

Given these major players (and there are more), for both consumer and B2E/B2B mobility strategies OEMs and Suppliers must ensure the receiver of the service on their mobile phone or tablet :

  1. Is able to access it on any device. Driver demographics in the US match mobile phone usage demographics closely, with around 50% owning smartphones – and of those iPhone, Android devices and Blackberries dominate. To ensure coverage a mobility solutions must cover smartphones, but also provide modern HTML5 mobile web experiences but with a graceful, feature-lite support for those feature phone owners with older mobile browsers
  2. Experiences a UX which is fully optimized for their own device, and every bit as well designed and delivered as other top mass-market consumer apps. Users who have an iPhone want their app to be a native iPhone app, for example, not a ‘lowest common denominator’ look-and-feel
  3. Is able to have their app updated quickly, easily and - depending on the use cases - regularly where new services and functionality are ready, or simply for bug fixes.

Specifically for B2E and B2B suppliers, to be able to deliver business applications to any mobile device they need to have tools which embrace the reality of BYOD (bring your own device to work) , and be able to deploy and manage their applications securely and easily from a central management console, via a dedicated Enterprise App Store.  For more information on Mobile Application Management click here. The opportunities for mobility in all sectors of the automotive business are staggering. The requirements for mobility in automotive call for a closer collaboration between all the major players in the game than ever before. My car just texted me – it wants to go meet with the cute Audi at Starbucks. I have to go…

On Monday, in a hastily-arranged press conference at the Milk Studios in Hollywood, Microsoft announced it has finally decided to try beating Apple at its own game, unveiling a sleek 10-inch, 9-mm wide, ARM-based tablet called Microsoft Surface. This tablet, Microsoft’s first foray into hardware since the ill-fated Kin phone a few years back, will run the new Microsoft Windows 8 RT OS, a slimmed-down version of Win8 optimized for ARM chips. While the media and Apple fans ponder Microsoft’s chances in this high-stakes game, our customers – and executives just like them who are responsible for their company’s mobility strategies – are wondering how seriously to take this new entry. Factors like price point, battery life, and pre-installed apps and games were conspicuously missing from this week’s announcement, but they all play a major role in whether this new platform gains traction in the market, or goes the way of the Zune and Kindevices before it. So, a few initial thoughts from the Kony team:

  1. The Microsoft Surface tablet is first and foremost a consumer device, optimized for consumer must-haves such as fast startup, touch interface, eye-catching graphics and screen resolution, etc. Its success will depend on its ability to appeal to consumers’ fickle tastes, price sensitivity, and perhaps, brand-consciousness.
  2. That said, consumers have a notable habit of blurring the lines between their home and business lives, bringing their devices in to work and requesting corporate IT support them with corporate applications and access to the company intranet and other networks. This is sometimes dubbed “Consumerization of IT” or “Bring Your Own Device”
  3. Because of this blurring, Microsoft’s bundling of Office apps, seamless support for Exchange, and, of course, the security and manageability of Windows itself – may become the features that spur this device’s success, at least among certain demographics.
  4. Longer term, Microsoft’s goal is to preserve and extend its flagship Windows brand, which means the Surface is part of a broader assault on Apple that will marshal a flotilla of tablet devices, laptops, ultra books, and even – gasp -- desktop machines, based on the new Windows 8 OS, starting this holiday season.
  5. Two days after the Surface announcement, Microsoft unveiled its latest plans for Windows Phone 8, the next generation of its revamped mobile platform. Among other enhancements including NFC and Skype support, Windows Phone 8 will share much of the same codebase with Windows 8, enabling developers to create apps that run seamlessly across phone, tablet, laptop and desktop – all downloadable from the Microsoft Store.

So how should mobility managers respond to all this? A couple of recommendations:

  1. If your mobility strategy targets consumers, we would recommend you keep an eye on this new tablet and monitor how well it delivers on the key apps, games, etc. consumers look for. Also note whether Microsoft can truly deliver a single app store for all devices, and watch to see whether developers deliver new compelling content on the Microsoft’s store. If you find the Surface gaining some traction in these areas, begin building a strategy for deploying select apps or your entire portfolio to it sometime next year.
  2. If you need to support mobile information workers who are bringing in their own devices, consider a pilot of the Microsoft Surface and some of the third-party Windows 8 tablets and ultrabooks over the next year. You may find at least some of these devices can meet end users’ need for instant-on, touch functionality while still meeting your need for corporate data security and improved manageability. In the meantime, if you haven’t already, have a look at Kony’s new Mobile Application Management technologies for provisioning, managing, securing and analyzing corporate mobile apps.
  3. For specialized mobile workers such as field service technicians, mobile pharmacy reps, transportation/logistics workers, and insurance agents, keep picking the device that best provides the form/function/ruggedization required – and don’t forget to check out Kony’s array of pre-packaged mobile business apps for these functions, available for all the major channels including – very soon – Windows 8.

Will Microsoft’s latest move be enough to stem the flow of iPads, iPhones and Android devices under our Christmas trees and into office environments this year? Probably not immediately, but Microsoft appears to be in this for the long haul. For our part, we don’t think this game is necessarily over yet.

Priorities and strategies appear to be consistent across the board marking, perhaps, a maturity in understanding around where mobility fits into an overall business mix for companies in general across industries.Some key results are worth discussing here in this blog : 1 in 4 report their mobile efforts are a ‘huge success’ and only 1 in 18 say it is a ‘huge failure.’ Self-reporting biases aside, the implication here is that firms have an agreed metric or set of metrics with which to measure a successful mobile deployment. Just a year ago the ‘gold rush’ to get mobilized led companies to eschew metrics in favor of a simple presence. Almost all mobile apps are developed and deployed within 12 months, with around half of consumer and business-oriented apps achieving a shelf-life of under a year. The costs associated with initial development of an application (or mobile website for that matter) are relatively small in comparison to care-and feeding expenses through the life-cycle. From a maturity standpoint it is clear many firms are now looking at a total-cost-of-ownership model to finance their mobile efforts, knowing that mobile is not a ‘test’ but is here to stay. Scar tissue from prior efforts helps in this endeavor, and although the management guru ‘fail fast’ mantra is understood, making practical decisions based on experience remains a complex and highly technical effort. On HTML5: despite the hype, HTML5 mobile web’s relative share is projected to stay stable. ‘Hybrid’ apps are emerging as workarounds to missing HTML5 functionality. HTML5 has clearly hit an inflection point, with desktop and mobile web developers now understanding more about its use in practice, and its challenges in compatibility across browsers (here and here are excellent references). However it is – and will continue to be - a critical part of any company’s mobile web strategy since all new tablet and smartphone browsers support a majority of HTML5 functionality.  But history tells us that any technology driven by a community that is financially unaccountable to its users will lose ground to those driven by traditional profit motives. Today this means apps. It means in-app purchases and in-app, highly targeted advertising. One recent example of a gaming company abandoning their HTML5 ‘experiment’ is Wooga. Around half of companies use a mobile application development platform, while half choose open source tools. On average one in three firms use a design agency to manage their life-cycle mobile efforts, while two-thirds rely on in-house development resources.  Roughly, agencies opt for open source and native tools, while in-house developers choose development platforms. Surveys such as this do make it clear that mobility as a whole is becoming better understood, and with that more informed decisions and strategies are starting to become the norm rather than the exception.

HTML5 has many of our customers and partners pondering how to incorporate the ever-evolving standard into their mobile software strategies. After all, analysts project that more than a billion HTML5-enabled phones will be in circulation by 2013, making up almost the entire population of smartphones in that year, and tripling the number of phones with mobile browsers that fully or partially support HTML5.For the enterprise, CIOs naturally want to be able to tap into the expertise of their web development teams, and do more to drive a unified development strategy that incorporates corporate, web, and mobile apps from a single development team. For mobile marketing and e-commerce execs, HTML5 offers a potential way to deliver a consistent user experience across smartphones and tablets, as well as a way to push updates and new features extremely rapidly. With the standard set for completionin 2014, debate rages in the industry over whether and how fast developers will migrate to HTML5 as their primary method of mobile app development and deployment. Here at Kony, we field the question daily: How should we approach HTML5, and what role does the Kony mobile application platform play in an HTML5 environment?  There are fundamentally three perspectives on this:

  • For CIOs and IT Directors driving corporate application strategies, HTML5 is – mostly – an opportunity, not a threat. By unleashing the talents of their web development teams to extend corporate apps to mobile devices, these CIOs can drive productivity and efficiency gains while meeting end-user demands for instant-on, media-rich mobile functionality, particularly for those apps that don’t require offline capability. The question for these IT chiefs is really around how to get there from here: with the standard still evolving and immature/untested in many ways, CIOs need to devise a strategy that takes advantage of what’s available now, while simultaneously laying the groundwork for future app development. With the substantial infrastructure needed to support HTML5 for mobile apps, we’ve found IT shops can get there faster, better, and with more long-term sustainability by utilizing the KonyOne Platform for their HTML5 and hybrid or mixed-mode HTML5/Native app development. To see how this breaks down into a vastly lower Total Cost of Ownership for HTML5 apps, please contact us to perform a detailed analysis of your environment.
  • For marketing and e-commerce execs - and really anyone charged with driving customer retention and loyalty - HTML5 is both an opportunity and a threat, best approached with extreme caution. On the one hand, there are those billion HTML5-enabled phones. On the other, there’s the need to deliver rich, compelling, “sticky” experiences to keep fickle consumers delighted and loyal – something that is next to impossible to deliver in HTML5 only. Plus, of course, there’s the issue of how to get consumers to notice and access your app in the first place, whether it’s mobile web-based or native. On this topic, at least one industry commentator sees native apps gaining the edge well into the foreseeable future, due to the simple fact that “pure” mobile web apps don’t appear in app stores, which are the primary destination for consumers looking for great mobile experiences. This can be mitigated with hybrid development focused on “wrapping” the mobile web code with native code, so that the app can appear in the app store, but this tactic introduces new complexities. At Kony we’re not taking sides – we’re just looking to help mobile marketers deliver the best functionality possible, utilizing all of the technologies at their disposal. For this reason, we’ve created pre-built apps that run in native and HTML5 modes across all the popular mobile channels, supported by our platform and configurability tools to give you even more options. For a detailed discussion of the ins and outs of HTML5 and native options for B2C apps, visit the webinars in our Resources Center.
  • For developers of all varieties, HTML5 is a huge opportunity, when handled in a smart and strategic way. The unfortunate reality for most developers, whether going with HTML5, native app development, or a hybrid combination of the two, is that creating mobile apps by hand is difficult, time consuming, and tedious.  Instead of being able to focus on what makes their apps great, developers spend most of their time dealing with getting the plumbing working; getting forms to appear and look correct on multiple devices; getting data to come back quickly and reliably; and dealing with an unending list of differences in what is supported ( or not ) on different platforms.  And while HTML5 was supposed to make this all go away (and make it easy for anyone to turn out a great cross-device mobile apps), the truth is that HTML5 is just as difficult to develop in and support as native application development, but for a host of different reasons.  (For a site that helps you figure out which of your features HTML5 supports and how, visit When Can I Use – also check out HTML5 Please). Factor in to this that there is little cross-browser agreement on how tags are implemented - or what features are supported - and HTML5 development can quickly become a spaghetti mess of browser detection scripts and unending CSS declarations. And by the way, some or alot of it may break with HTML6.

So for developers, we recommend this: Figure out whether HTML5 makes sense for the use cases and end users you’re targeting; figure out how much of your target app you can cover using HTML5 (in our experience this is generally between 40 and 70 percent), then build a strategy for how you’ll create your first version - which is likely to be some type of hybrid - and how you might be able to migrate that to HTML5 as the standard evolves and if your app’s requirements demand it.The KonyOne platform supports this process because it lets you create your application definition one time with the KonyOne Studio, and then let Kony’s build process generate native app, hybrids, wrappers and browser-specific outputs.  As the mobile environment changes, Kony handles keeping up with the details with our SLA, letting you focus on delivering amazing applications.  Instead of having to tell your business that you can’t deliver new functionality because you are still supporting the old application, you can be building out world class applications, knowing that they’ll work regardless of what channels the business wants to support, or what changes the OS and device manufacturers make.  Not only are you ready to deploy for HTML5 (with outputs tailored for each browser), you can also generate native iOS, Android, Windows Phone, Blackberry, Symbian, Web OS, and JavaME apps – if that’s what your business needs.  Bottom line, the KonyOne Studio allows you to focus on delivering the business value instead of getting bogged down in the minutiae of hand coding for your mobile development. There’s no doubt about it: HTML5 is an exciting development for our industry. With the right strategy, tools, and team, business managers and developers of all types should be able to leverage it to design stunning mobile experiences for their end-users – watch this space for more thoughts from our team around how to do just that.

Develop: Instead of a proprietary language or SDK, Kony delivers a Javascript-based, Eclipse plug-in IDE..   • Microsoft SharePoint
  • Content management systems (CMS)

und.safe_value: So you have a mobile strategy, but all of a sudden your mobile developers and architects are starting to talk about something new: multi-channel. Multi-channel use cases, management, analysis – the whole enchilada. So what is multi-channel anyway? We can answer that question with three distinct, but related, concepts : 1) Same app, any screen. Whether your end users are employees, consumers or partners, chances are they own or have been issued several types of devices. At a minimum they have a desktop machine and a phone, and expect to access their email, calendar, apps, games, media and more on both - seamlessly and with the experience optimized for each form factor. But increasingly, many have a desktop or laptop, plus a phone, plus a tablet, and very soon, a smart TV. On top of the devices they carry, users will soon also expect seamless access to their apps and more on kiosks, in-dash systems, home automation systems and game consoles.  The multi-channel vision is to give these users access to everything they want, on any device, including but not limited to their mobile phones. In other words, including their 32-bit desktop and desktop web experiences and indeed, every automated system they encounter. Consider a day in the life of a sales manager: When she wakes up in the morning, chances are very good that she has her smartphone in hand within moments. She checks email, calendar, and maybe one or two native or hybrid apps that give her news, weather, stock information or important sports scores. In the parking lot at a customer site after a rushed coffee and bagel, before her visit she uses the instant-on, touch-screen convenience of her tablet to check her CRM system wirelessly, accessing the customer’s key account information, order history, and notes from their last meeting. After the meeting and in the same parking lot - using a few simple buttons and selecting mostly from pull-down options - she may update the CRM system from that tablet before heading to the office. Once in the office, she’ll want to access the whole array of corporate systems from her laptop or desktop machine – but the look and feel of what she encounters on her connected monitor and through keyboard/mouse interactions are fundamentally different and more detailed than what she accessed earlier in the day on her mobile devices. und.safe_value: It is no secret that Facebook is struggling with how to best monetize their mobile channel. Recent comScore stats confirm what we all suspected - that users are now spending more Facebook time on smartphones and tablets than on its desktop website experience. And for the smartphone audience, specifically, the split is around 80/20 between Facebook native app and Facebook mobile web visits.  To date Facebook’s answer is to drop ads into News Feeds – the ‘sponsored by’ stories and links we all really enjoy seeing – but this can go only so far before disenfranchising the entire user base and turning Facebook’s News Feed into the equivalent of email inbox spam. Last week Facebook did an impressive about-turn from their much vaunted HTML5-dominant mobile app strategy and released a mainly native (Objective C) version 5 for iOS, which doubles the speed of many features.  Of course this doesn’t mean the demise of HTML5 with Facebook – far from it. But it does say that users will not compromise on the perceived performance of key application areas. Although Facebook’s iOS Product Manager states that this revamp was conducted  ‘…over the last 9 months..’ –indicating their original HTML5 app was quickly marked as needing improvement – the timing is suspicious. iOS 6 is coming out this week on the back of the new iPhone, and one notable new feature area is a deep Facebook integration of apps such as Safari, Camera, Notification Center and Maps.  iOS users will be able to interact with most common Facebook use cases without leaving these apps. No Facebook app for user-generated content interactions means an even more challenging monetization problem.  Realizing traffic to Facebook apps will inevitably decline for iOS users posting content, perhaps sprucing up their iOS app and reducing its preponderance of HTML5 components will help keep eyeballs there longer?

This is also described on our developer portal site.

und.safe_value: It’s probably not news to you that BYOD – bring your own device - will soon require action from your enterprise.  Your options are to start working now to embrace it, or continue to enforce policies that restrict mobile devices within your infrastructure.   Either way, BYOD is a new fact of life for IT managers because of today’s mobile workforce. Employees increasingly telecommute, spend time on airplanes or work in the field.  Easy access to company apps and information on personal devices and at locations outside the office building has become something of an imperative to many employees.  Enterprises understand the value and efficiency of giving employees access to business critical information on the go, but deep concerns about security and privacy have held many back.   But the good news is there is a new generation of Mobile Application Management (MAM) software solutions available to directly address the challenges associated with BYOD deployments. Most companies already authorize email access on most devices.  But it is possible to implement the same level of control and security over all corporate applications, devices and content using MAM - which is distinguished from Mobile Device Management (MDM) because it takes a software and data-focused approach vs. a hardware-based approach to application and data management. Kony in particular has worked on fine-tuning its MAM offering to give IT the security and control they need, while allowing employees to get work done faster from the comfort of their own devices.  Kony’s MAM suite allows IT to create policy-based rules for application access based on roles, locations, specific business hours, and domains. Another key feature of Kony’s MAM is the concept of a “Secure Mobile Application Management Container” that completely abstracts applications and data away from the specifics of the device and operating system. Kony’s secure mobile application container provides a separate and secure virtual environment on the mobile device in which to run Kony and non-Kony applications and store related data. Kony MAM also offers analytics so IT can track the type and amount of usage by employees, to understand better how to scale and quickly address gaps in the mobility portfolio.. With MAM, BYOD need not be something to loathe or be the subject of constant procrastination. Here’s a quick 3-minute demo of our MAM solution at work.
